raw_comment:
Notice:
-Many applicants whom have a richer family and have more of a family legacy are almost always excepted into the colleges, while those without family legacies and are more on the poor side aren't excepted into the ivy leagues colleges. 
-They used gray and black colors, but the also used gray filling in the graph so it was confusing to understand at first. 

Wonder:
- Why do colleges care and accept richer family legacy applicants over applicants who may be just as good, but don't have a family legacy?
- How does mostly excepting family legacy applicant effect how much money is being poured into the college? 

Community:
- At my school, there are a few family's that already have legacies in the high school, and a lot of them want to get into the ivy league schools.

Headline: 
"Excepted Legacy or Not?"
ace_sentences: Many applicants have a richer family.
Many applicants have a family legacy.
Many colleges accept these applicants.
Some applicants do not have a family legacy.
Some applicants are poor.
Many Ivy League colleges do not accept these applicants.
The graph uses gray and black colors.
The graph also uses gray filling.
This use is confusing.
At first, it is hard to understand the graph.
Some applicants are as good as other applicants.
Some colleges care about family legacy.
I ask why colleges accept richer applicants with a family legacy.
I ask why colleges do not accept applicants without a family legacy.
Some colleges mostly accept family legacy applicants.
I ask how this affects the money that is poured into a college.
I go to a school.
At my school, a few families have legacies in the high school.
Many students from these families want to get into Ivy League schools.
The headline is: Excepted Legacy or Not?
